conclusion: The problem involves finding the van der Waals constants \(a\) and \(b\) in terms of the critical temperature \(T_c\) and critical pressure \(P_c\), using the van der Waals equation of state and critical point conditions.
The van der Waals equation of state is given as \( \left( P + \frac{a}{V^2} \right) (V - b) = RT \).
At the critical point, the pressure \(P_c\), volume \(V_c\), and temperature \(T_c\) satisfy the van der Waals equation.
From the equation \( P_c (V_c - b) = RT_c \), solving for \(b\) gives \( b = \frac{P_c V_c - RT_c}{P_c} \).
Substituting \(b = \frac{P_c V_c - RT_c}{P_c} \) into the second critical point equation leads to \( \left( P_c + \frac{a}{V_c^2} \right) \left( \frac{RT_c}{P_c} \right) = RT_c \).
Simplifying the substituted equation results in \( \left( P_c + \frac{a}{V_c^2} \right) = P_c \), which implies \( \frac{a}{V_c^2} = 0 \), but this is incorrect since \(a \neq 0\).
To resolve the issue, the derivative of the van der Waals equation with respect to \(V\) is taken: \( \frac{\partial}{\partial V} \left( \left( P + \frac{a}{V^2} \right) (V - b) \right) = 0 \).
The derivative is expanded as \( \left( \frac{\partial P}{\partial V} \right)_{T} (V - b) + \left( P + \frac{a}{V^2} \right) \left( \frac{\partial V}{\partial V} \right)_{T} = 0 \).
At the critical point, \( \left( \frac{\partial P}{\partial V} \right)_{T} = -\frac{\partial}{\partial V} \left( \frac{a}{V^2} \right) = \frac{2a}{V^3} \).
Substituting \( \left( \frac{\partial P}{\partial V} \right)_{T} = \frac{2a}{V_c^3} \) into the derivative equation gives \( \frac{2a}{V_c^3} (V_c - b) + \left( P_c + \frac{a}{V_c^2} \right) = 0 \).
Substituting \( b = \frac{P_c V_c - RT_c}{P_c} \) into the derivative equation results in \( \frac{2a}{V_c^3} \left( \frac{RT_c}{P_c} \right) + \left( P_c + \frac{a}{V_c^2} \right) = 0 \).
